It is a best practice to use a risk-based assessment when evaluating a change request. This approach helps identify factors that may disrupt the business or impede the delivery of services. Different approaches can be taken to assess and manage risks, and each organization must determine the approach it wants to use. Different ways to establish risk include the following:

  • Manually select the risk
  • Risk assessments
  • Risk conditions

Configure risk assessments or conditions to enable dynamic calculations of the risk of a change request.

false change /risk_conditions_list.do 3 1 false true There are a few different ways to establish the risk of a change record. The most basic way is to the let requester choose from the choice list. This way is not typically recommended because different people assess risk in different ways. This way can also be misused as the requester can select a risk that they know avoids CAB authorization.

There are two methods to automatically calculate the risk of a change based on standardized criteria:

Risk conditions
Risk conditions allow you to calculate the risk using information entered into the change record. For example, it is possible to automatically establish the risk of the change based on the CI that is added to the change record.
Risk assessments
Risk assessments use a survey-style approach to present questions to the change requester. Based on the answers, the risk level is calculated. Each organization determines risk in different ways, but some questions that are regularly asked include:
  • What is the complexity of the change?
  • Has this type of change been successfully implemented in the past?
  • How many users are impacted?
  • Does this change impact a critical business service?
  • How many resources or groups are involved in implementing the change?
  • Is the change during a freeze period?
  • How long does the change take to implement?
  • How long does the change take to back out?
  • How difficult is the change to back out?
  • Does the change require an outage?
  • Has this change been implemented in a pre-production environment?

Assessing risk accurately is one of the most challenging parts of the Change Management process. It requires regular review and refinement over time.

If you use risk conditions or risk assessment, it is recommended that you make the Risk field read-only for all users except the change manager. This action prevents the automatically calculated risk level from being altered.

Add an access control rule to set the Risk to read-only based on this recommendation.
